p.s: Description of Neisseria polysaccharea sp. nov.
Neisseria polysaccharea (poly. Gr. adj. poly, many; sac. cha. rae. Gr. n. Saccharum, sugar; poly.sac.cha.rae. M.L. fem. adj. polysaccharea, with many saccharides)
Gram-negative unencapsulated cocci arranged in pairs or tetrads.
Oxidative respiratory metabolism, Oxidase and catalase produced.
All strains grow on selective medium (Gono-Meningo agar; Diagnostics Pasteur, Marnes-la-Coquette, France) producing yellowish colonies of about 2 mm in diameter after 24 h at 37¬∞C.
No growth occurs at 22¬∞C.
Large amounts of polysaccharides are produced on solid or in liquid medium containing 1 or 5% sucrose.
Requires cystine-cysteine to grow on Neisseria defined medium (3); in addition, some strains require arginine.
Acid is produced from glucose and maltose, rarely from sucrose, but never from fructose, mannitol, or lactose.
Tributyrin and o-nitrophenyl-Œ≤-D-galactopyranoside are not hydrolyzed.
Nitrites are reduced, nitrates are not.
Deoxyribonuclease, gelatinase, and ùõæ-glutamyltransferase are not produced.
No hemolysis is observed on horse blood agar.
The G+C content of the DNA is 53 ¬± 1.5 mol% (mean ¬± standard deviation).
Isolated from the pharynx of infants and children.
No strain of this species has been recognized as a cause of a human disease.
The type strain is strain CIP 100113 = NCTC 11858.
Description of type strain.
Strain CIP 100113 (NCTC 11.85gT) was isolated from a human throat in 1975 and has all the properties given for the species.
It requires cystinecysteine to grow on Neisseria defined medium.
Acid is produced only from glucose and maltose.
The G+C content of the DNA is 55.5 mol%.
